para.sentence: Let \mathbf{X} be a point set with a limit point c.
As x\to c in \mathbf{X} \displaystyle f(x)\sim\phi(x)\Longleftrightarrow f(x)/\phi(x)\to 1.
, \displaystyle f(x)=o\left(\phi(x)\right)\Longleftrightarrow f(x)/\phi(x)\to 0.
, \displaystyle f(x)=O\left(\phi(x)\right)\Longleftrightarrow|f(x)/\phi(x)|\text { is bounded. } The symbol O can also apply to the whole set \mathbf{X} , and not just as x\to c.
\tanh x\sim x, subject to x\to 0 in \mathbb{C}.
e^{-x}=o\left(1\right), subject to x\to+\infty in \mathbb{R}.
\sin\left(\pi x+x^{-1}\right)=O\left(x^{-1}\right), subject to x\to\pm\infty in \mathbb{Z}.
e^{ix}=O\left(1\right), subject to x\in\mathbb{R}.
In (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.E) \mathbb{R} can be replaced by any fixed ray in the sector |\operatorname{ph}x|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , or by the whole of the sector |\operatorname{ph}x|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi-\delta.

(Here and elsewhere in this chapter \delta is an arbitrary small positive constant.)But ( LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.E) does not hold as x\to\infty in |\operatorname{ph}x|<\frac{1}{2}\pi (for example, set x=1+it and let t\to\pm\infty.
If \sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}z^{s} converges for all sufficiently small |z| , then for each nonnegative integer n \sum_{s=n}^{\infty}a_{s}z^{s}=O\left(z^{n}\right), subject to z\to 0 in \mathbb{C}.
e^{z}=1+z+O\left(z^{2}\right), subject to z\to 0 in \mathbb{C}.
The symbols o and O can be used generically.
For example, o\left(\phi\right)=O\left(\phi\right), o\left(\phi\right)+o\left(\phi\right)=o\left(\phi\right) it being understood that these equalities are not reversible.
(In other words = here really means \subseteq.
Integration of asymptotic and order relations is permissible, subject to obvious convergence conditions.
For example, suppose f(x) is continuous and f(x)\sim x^{\nu} as x\to+\infty in \mathbb{R} , where \nu ( \in\mathbb{C} ) is a constant.
Differentiation requires extra conditions.
This result also holds with both O ’s replaced by o ’s.

Let \sum a_{s}x^{-s} be a formal power series (convergent or divergent) and for each positive integer n , f(x)=\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}a_{s}x^{-s}+O\left(x^{-n}\right) as x\to\infty in an unbounded set \mathbf{X} in \mathbb{R} or \mathbb{C}.
Then \sum a_{s}x^{-s} is a Poincaré asymptotic expansion, or simply asymptotic expansion, of f(x) as x\to\infty in \mathbf{X}.
Symbolically, f(x)\sim a_{0}+a_{1}x^{-1}+a_{2}x^{-2}+\cdots, subject to x\to\infty in \mathbf{X}.
Condition (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.M) is equivalent to x^{n}\left(f(x)-\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}a_{s}x^{-s}\right)\to a_{n}, subject to x\to\infty in \mathbf{X}, for each n=0,1,2,\dots.
If \sum a_{s}x^{-s} converges for all sufficiently large |x| , then it is automatically the asymptotic expansion of its sum as x\to\infty in \mathbb{C}.

If c is a finite limit point of \mathbf{X} , then f(x)\sim a_{0}+a_{1}(x-c)+a_{2}(x-c)^{2}+\cdots, subject to x\to c in \mathbf{X}, means that for each n , the difference between f(x) and the n th partial sum on the right-hand side is O\left((x-c)^{n}\right) as x\to c in \mathbf{X}.
Most operations on asymptotic expansions can be carried out in exactly thesame manner as for convergent power series.
These include addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.
Substitution, logarithms, and powers are also permissible; compare ( , pp. 19–22) .
Differentiation, however, requires the kind of extra conditions needed for the O symbol (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEP.ID).
For reversion see §LABEL:sec:AS.TE.
Some asymptotic approximations are expressed in terms of two or more Poincaré asymptotic expansions.

In those cases it is usually necessary to interpret each infinite series separately in the manner described above; that is, it is not always possible to reinterpret the asymptotic approximation as a single asymptotic expansion.
For an example see (LABEL:eq:AS.DEWP.L).
Asymptotic expansions of the forms (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.N), (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.P) are unique.

But for any given set of coefficients a_{0},a_{1},a_{2},\dots , and suitably restricted \mathbf{X} there is an infinity of analytic functions f(x) such that (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.N) and (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.P) apply.
For (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.N) \mathbf{X} can be the positive real axis or any unbounded sector in \mathbb{C} of finite angle.

As an example, in the sector |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi-\delta ( <\frac{1}{2}\pi ) each of the functions 0,e^{-z} , and e^{-\sqrt{z}} (principal value) has the null asymptotic expansion 0+0\cdot z^{-1}+0\cdot z^{-2}+\cdots, subject to z\to\infty.

If the set \mathbf{X} in §LABEL:sec:AS.DEP.AE is a closed sector \alpha\leq\operatorname{ph}x\leq\beta , then by definition the asymptotic property (LABEL:eq:AS.DEP.M) holds uniformly with respect to \operatorname{ph}x\in[\alpha,\beta] as |x|\to\infty.
The asymptotic property may also hold uniformly with respect to parameters.

Suppose u is a parameter (or set of parameters) ranging over a point set (or sets) \mathbf{U} , and for each nonnegative integer n \left|x^{n}\left(f(u,x)-\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}a_{s}(u)x^{-s}\right)\right| is bounded as x\to\infty in \mathbf{X} , uniformly for u\in\mathbf{U}.
(The coefficients a_{s}(u) may now depend on u.
) Then f(u,x)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}(u)x^{-s} as x\to\infty in \mathbf{X} , uniformly with respect to u\in\mathbf{U}.
Similarly for finite limit point c in place of \infty.

Let \phi_{s}(x) , s=0,1,2,\dots , be a sequence of functions defined in \mathbf{X} such that for each s \phi_{s+1}(x)=o\left(\phi_{s}(x)\right), subject to x\to c in \mathbf{X}, where c is a finite, or infinite, limit point of \mathbf{X}.
Then \{\phi_{s}(x)\} is an asymptotic sequence or scale.
Suppose also that f(x) and f_{s}(x) satisfy f(x)=\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}f_{s}(x)+O\left(\phi_{n}(x)\right), subject to x\to c in \mathbf{X}, for n=0,1,2,\dots.
Then \sum f_{s}(x) is a generalized asymptotic expansion of f(x) with respect to the scale \{\phi_{s}(x)\}.
Symbolically, f(x)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}f_{s}(x);\;\;\{\phi_{s}(x)\}, subject to x\to c in \mathbf{X}.
As in §LABEL:sec:AS.DEP.UAE, generalized asymptotic expansions can also have uniformity properties with respect to parameters.
For an example see §LABEL:sec:LE.UAA.LOFD.
Care is needed in understanding and manipulating generalized asymptotic expansions.
Many properties enjoyed by Poincaré expansions (for example, multiplication) do not always carry over.
It can even happen that a generalized asymptotic expansion converges, but its sum is not the function being represented asymptotically; for an example see §LABEL:sec:OP.AA.Le.
Let f(x) be continuous and strictly increasing when a<x<\infty and f(x)\sim x, subject to x\to\infty.
Then for y>f(a) the equation f(x)=y has a unique root x=x(y) in (a,\infty) , and x(y)\sim y, subject to y\to\infty.
With x=t^{2} , f(x)=x-\frac{1}{2}\ln x.
We may take a=\frac{1}{2}.
From (LABEL:eq:AS.TE.B) t=y^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(1+o\left(1\right)\right), subject to y\to\infty.
Higher approximations are obtainable by successive resubstitutions.
For example t^{2}=y+\ln t=y+\tfrac{1}{2}\ln y+o\left(1\right), and hence t=y^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(1+\tfrac{1}{4}y^{-1}\ln y+o\left(y^{-1}\right)\right), subject to y\to\infty.
An important case is the reversion of asymptotic expansions for zeros of special functions.
In place of (LABEL:eq:AS.TE.A) assume that f(x)\sim x+f_{0}+f_{1}x^{-1}+f_{2}x^{-2}+\cdots, subject to x\to\infty.

Then x\sim y-F_{0}-F_{1}y^{-1}-F_{2}y^{-2}-\cdots, subject to y\to\infty, where F_{0}=f_{0} and sF_{s} ( s\geq 1 ) is the coefficient of x^{-1} in the asymptotic expansion of (f(x))^{s} (Lagrange’s formula for the reversion of series).
Conditions for the validity of the reversion process in \mathbb{C} are derived in ( , pp. 14–16) .
Applications to real and complex zeros of Airy functions are given in ( ) .
For other examples see ( , Chapter 2) .
Assume that the Laplace transform \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-xt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t converges for all sufficiently large x , and q(t) is infinitely differentiable in a neighborhood of the origin.
Then \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-xt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{q^{(s)}(0) }{x^{s+1}}, subject to x\to+\infty.

If, in addition, q(t) is infinitely differentiable on [0,\infty) and \sigma_{n}=\sup_{(0,\infty)}(t^{-1}\ln|q^{(n)}(t)/q^{(n)}(0)|) is finite and bounded for n=0,1,2,\dots , then the n th error term (that is, the difference between the integral and n th partial sum in (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.B)) is bounded in absolute value by |q^{(n)}(0)/(x^{n}(x-\sigma_{n}))| when x exceeds both 0 and \sigma_{n}.
For the Fourier integral \int_{a}^{b}e^{ixt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t assume a and b are finite, and q(t) is infinitely differentiable on [a,b].

Then \int_{a}^{b}e^{ixt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim e^{iax}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}q^{(s)}(a) \left(\frac{i}{x}\right)^{s+1}-e^{ibx}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}q^{(s)}(b)\left(\frac {i}{x}\right)^{s+1}, subject to x\to+\infty.

Alternatively, assume b=\infty , q(t) is infinitely differentiable on [a,\infty) , and each of the integrals \int e^{ixt}q^{(s)}(t)\mathrm{d}t , s=0,1,2,\dots , converges as t\to\infty uniformly for all sufficiently large x.
Then \int_{a}^{\infty}e^{ixt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim e^{iax}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}q^{(s)}( a)\left(\frac{i}{x}\right)^{s+1}, subject to x\to+\infty.

In both cases the n th error term is bounded in absolute value by x^{-n}\mathcal{V}_{a,b}\left(q^{(n-1)}(t)\right) , where the variational operator \mathcal{V}_{a,b} is defined by \mathcal{V}_{a,b}\left(f(t)\right)=\int_{a}^{b}|f^{\prime}(t)\mathrm{d}t|; see §LABEL:sec:AL.COO.di.
For other examples, see ( , Chapter 1) .

Assume again that the integral (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.A) converges for all sufficiently large x , but now q(t)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}t^{(s+\lambda-\mu)/\mu}, subject to t\to 0+, where \lambda and \mu are positive constants.

Then the series obtained by substituting (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F) into (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.A) and integrating formally term by term yields an asymptotic expansion: \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-xt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma\left( \frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s}}{x^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}, subject to x\to+\infty.
For the function \Gamma see §LABEL:sec:GA.Def.GP.
This result is probably the most frequently used method for deriving asymptotic expansions of special functions.
Since q(t) need not be continuous (as long as the integral converges), the case of a finite integration range is included.
Other types of singular behavior in the integrand can be treated in an analogous manner.

For example, \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-xt}q(t)\ln t\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma' \left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s}}{x^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}-(\ln x) \sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma\left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s}}{x^{(s+ \lambda)/\mu}}, provided that the integral on the left-hand side of (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.H) converges for all sufficiently large values of x.
(In other words, differentiation of (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.G) with respect to the parameter \lambda (or \mu ) is legitimate.)
Another extension is to more general factors than the exponential function.

In addition to (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F) assume that f(t) and q(t) are piecewise continuous (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.C) on (0,\infty) , and |f(t)|\leq A\exp\left(-at^{\kappa}\right), subject to 0\leq t<\infty, q(t)=O\left(\exp\left(bt^{\kappa}\right)\right), subject to t\to+\infty, where A,a,b,\kappa are positive constants.

Then \int_{0}^{\infty}f(xt)q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\mathscr{M}\mskip- 3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s}}{x^{(s+ \lambda)/\mu}}, subject to x\to+\infty, where \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(\alpha\right) is the Mellin transform of f(t) (§LABEL:sec:AS.MTM.I).
For a more detailed treatment of the integral (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.K) see §§LABEL:sec:AS.MTM, LABEL:sec:AS.DM.

When p(t) is real and x is a large positive parameter, the main contribution to the integral I(x)=\int_{a}^{b}e^{-xp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t derives from the neighborhood of the minimum of p(t) in the integration range.
Without loss of generality, we assume that this minimum is at the left endpoint a.
Furthermore: p^{\prime}(t) and q(t) are continuous in a neighborhood of a , save possibly at a , and the minimum of p(t) in [a,b) is approached only at a.
As t\to a+ p(t)\sim p(a)+\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}p_{s}(t-a)^{s+\mu}, q(t)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}q_{s}(t-a)^{s+\lambda-1}, and the expansion for p(t) is differentiable.
Again \lambda and \mu are positive constants.
Also p_{0}>0 (consistent with (a)).
The integral (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.L) converges absolutely for all sufficiently large x.

Then \int_{a}^{b}e^{-xp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim e^{-xp(a)}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma \left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{b_{s}}{x^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}, subject to x\to+\infty, where the coefficients b_{s} are defined by the expansion \frac{q(t)}{p^{\prime}(t)}\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}b_{s}v^{(s+\lambda-\mu)/\mu}, subject to v\to 0+, in which v=p(t)-p(a).
In general b_{s}=\frac{1}{\mu}\Residue_{t=a}\left[\frac{q(t)}{(p(t)-p(a))^{(\lambda+s)/ \mu}}\right], subject to s=0,1,2,\dots.
Watson’s lemma can be regarded as a special case of this result.
For error bounds for Watson’s lemma and Laplace’s method see ( ) and ( , Chapter 3) .
These references and ( , Chapter 2) also contain examples.

When the parameter x is large the contributions from the real and imaginary parts of the integrand in I(x)=\int_{a}^{b}e^{ixp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t oscillate rapidly and cancel themselves over most of the range.

However, cancellation does not take place near the endpoints, owing to lack of symmetry,nor in the neighborhoods of zeros of p^{\prime}(t) because p(t) changes relatively slowly at these stationary points.
The first result is the analog of Watson’s lemma (§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.WL).

Assume that q(t) again has the expansion (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F) and this expansion is infinitely differentiable, q(t) is infinitely differentiable on (0,\infty) , and each of the integrals \int e^{ixt}q^{(s)}(t)\mathrm{d}t , s=0,1,2,\dots , converges at t=\infty , uniformly for all sufficiently large x.

Then \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{ixt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\exp\left(\frac{ (s+\lambda)\pi i}{2\mu}\right)\Gamma\left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_ {s}}{x^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}, subject to x\to+\infty, where the coefficients a_{s} are given by (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F).

For the more general integral (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.Q) we assume, without loss ofgenerality, that the stationary point (if any) is at the left endpoint. Furthermore: On (a,b) , p(t) and q(t) are infinitely differentiable and p^{\prime}(t)>0.
As t\to a+ the asymptotic expansions (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.M) apply, and each is infinitely differentiable.
Again \lambda , \mu , and p_{0} are positive.

If the limit p(b) of p(t) as t\to b- is finite, then each of the functions P_{s}(t)=\left(\frac{1}{p^{\prime}(t)}\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\right)^{s }\frac{q(t)}{p^{\prime}(t)}, subject to s=0,1,2,\dots, tends to a finite limit P_{s}(b).
If p(b)=\infty , then P_{0}(b)=0 and each of the integrals \int e^{ixp(t)}P_{s}(t)p^{\prime}(t)\mathrm{d}t, subject to s=0,1,2,\dots, converges at t=b uniformly for all sufficiently large x.

If p(b) is finite, then both endpoints contribute: \int_{a}^{b}e^{ixp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim e^{ixp(a)}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\exp \left(\frac{(s+\lambda)\pi i}{2\mu}\right)\Gamma\left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu} \right)\frac{b_{s}}{x^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}-e^{ixp(b)}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}P_{s}(b) \left(\frac{i}{x}\right)^{s+1}, subject to x\to+\infty.
But if (d) applies, then the second sum is absent.
The coefficients b_{s} are defined as in §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.LM.
For proofs of the results of this subsection, error bounds, and an example, see ( ) .
For other estimates of the error term see ( ) .
For extensions to oscillatory integrals with logarithmic singularities see ( ) .

subsection.title: Coalescing Peak and Endpoint: Bleistein’s Method

para.sentence: In the integral I(\alpha,x)=\int_{0}^{k}e^{-xp(\alpha,t)}q(\alpha,t)t^{\lambda-1}\mathrm{d}t k ( \leq\infty ) and \lambda are positive constants, \alpha is a variable parameter in an interval \alpha_{1}\leq\alpha\leq\alpha_{2} with \alpha_{1}\leq 0 and 0<\alpha_{2}\leq k , and x is a large positive parameter.

Assume also that \ifrac{{\partial}^{2}p(\alpha,t)}{{\partial t}^{2}} and q(\alpha,t) are continuous in \alpha and t , and for each \alpha the minimum value of p(\alpha,t) in [0,k) is at t=\alpha , at which point \ifrac{\partial p(\alpha,t)}{\partial t} vanishes, but both \ifrac{{\partial}^{2}p(\alpha,t)}{{\partial t}^{2}} and q(\alpha,t) are nonzero.
When x\to+\infty Laplace’s method (§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.LM) applies, but the form of the resulting approximation is discontinuous at \alpha=0.
In consequence, the approximation is nonuniform with respect to \alpha and deteriorates severely as \alpha\to 0.

A uniform approximation can be constructed by quadratic change of integration variable: p(\alpha,t)=\tfrac{1}{2}w^{2}-aw+b, where a and b are functions of \alpha chosen in such a way that t=0 corresponds to w=0 , and the stationary points t=\alpha and w=a correspond.

Thus a=(2p(\alpha,0)-2p(\alpha,\alpha))^{1/2}, b=p(\alpha,0), w=(2p(\alpha,0)-2p(\alpha,\alpha))^{1/2}\pm(2p(\alpha,t)-2p(\alpha,\alpha))^{1 /2}, the upper or lower sign being taken according as t\gtrless\alpha.

The relationship between t and w is one-to-one, and because \frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}t}=\pm\frac{1}{(2p(\alpha,t)-2p(\alpha,\alpha))^{ 1/2}}\frac{\partial p(\alpha,t)}{\partial t} it is free from singularity at t=\alpha.

The integral (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.V) transforms into I(\alpha,x)=e^{-xp(\alpha,0)}\*\int_{0}^{\kappa}\exp\left(-x\left(\tfrac{1}{2} w^{2}-aw\right)\right)f(\alpha,w)w^{\lambda-1}\mathrm{d}w, where f(\alpha,w)=q(\alpha,t)\left(\frac{t}{w}\right)^{\lambda-1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{ \mathrm{d}w}, \kappa=\kappa(\alpha) being the value of w at t=k.

We now expand f(\alpha,w) in a Taylor series centered at the peak value w=a of the exponential factor in the integrand: f(\alpha,w)=\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\phi_{s}(\alpha)(w-a)^{s}, with the coefficients \phi_{s}(\alpha) continuous at \alpha=0.
The desired uniform expansion is then obtained formally as in Watson’s lemma and Laplace’s method.

We replace the limit \kappa by \infty and integrate term-by-term: I(\alpha,x)\sim\frac{e^{-xp(\alpha,0)}}{x^{\lambda/2}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\phi_ {s}(\alpha)\frac{F_{s}(a\sqrt{x})}{x^{s/2}}, subject to x\to\infty, where F_{s}(y)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\tfrac{1}{2}\tau^{2}+y\tau\right)(\tau-y) ^{s}\tau^{\lambda-1}\mathrm{d}\tau.
For examples and proofs see ( , Chapter 9) , ( ) , ( , Chapter 9) , and ( , Chapter 7) .
The result in §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.WL carries over to a complex parameter z.

Except that \lambda is now permitted to be complex, with \Re\lambda>0 , we assume the same conditions on q(t) and also that the Laplace transform in (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.G) converges for all sufficiently large values of \Re z.

Then \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma\left( \frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s}}{z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}} as z\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi-\delta ( <\frac{1}{2}\pi ), with z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu} assigned its principal value.
If q(t) is analytic in a sector \alpha_{1}<\operatorname{ph}t<\alpha_{2} containing \operatorname{ph}t=0 , then the region of validity may be increased by rotation of the integration paths.

We assume that in any closed sector with vertex t=0 and properly interior to \alpha_{1}<\operatorname{ph}t<\alpha_{2} , the expansion (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F) holds as t\to 0 , and q(t)=O\left(e^{\sigma|t|}\right) as t\to\infty , where \sigma is a constant.
Then ( LABEL:eq:AS.CI.A) is valid in any closed sector with vertex z=0 and properly interior to -\alpha_{2}-\frac{1}{2}\pi<\operatorname{ph}z<-\alpha_{1}+\frac{1}{2}\pi.
(The branches of t^{(s+\lambda-\mu)/\mu} and z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu} are extended by continuity.)
For examples and extensions (including uniformity and loop integrals) see ( , Chapter 4) , ( , Chapter 1) , and ( ) .
On the interval 0<t<\infty let q(t) be differentiable and e^{-ct}q(t) be absolutely integrable, where c is a real constant.
Then the Laplace transform Q(z)=\int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-zt}q(t)\mathrm{d}t is continuous in \Re z\geq c and analytic in \Re z>c , and by inversion (§LABEL:sec:AL.IT.lt)
q(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\lim\limits_{\eta\to\infty}\int_{\sigma-i\eta}^{\sigma+i \eta}e^{tz}Q(z)\mathrm{d}z, subject to 0<t<\infty, where \sigma ( \geq c ) is a constant.

Now assume that c>0 and we are given a function Q(z) that is both analytic and has the expansion Q(z)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma\left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right)\frac{a_{s} }{z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}}, subject to z\to\infty, in the half-plane \Re z\geq c.
Here \Re\lambda>0 , \mu>0 , and z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu} has its principal value.
Assume also(LABEL:eq:AS.CI.D) is differentiable.

Then by integration by parts the integral q(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\sigma-i\infty}^{\sigma+i\infty}e^{tz}Q(z)\mathrm{d }z, subject to 0<t<\infty, is seen to converge absolutely at each limit, and be independent of \sigma\in[c,\infty).
Furthermore, as t\to 0+ , q(t) has the expansion (LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.F).
For large t , the asymptotic expansion of q(t) may be obtained from (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.C) by Haar’s method.

This depends on the availability of a comparison function F(z) for Q(z) that has an inverse transform f(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\lim\limits_{\eta\to\infty}\int_{\sigma-i\eta}^{\sigma+i \eta}e^{tz}F(z)\mathrm{d}z with known asymptotic behavior as t\to+\infty.
By subtraction from (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.C) q(t)-f(t)=\frac{e^{\sigma t}}{2\pi}\lim\limits_{\eta\to\infty}\int_{-\eta}^{ \eta}e^{it\tau}(Q(\sigma+i\tau)-F(\sigma+i\tau))\mathrm{d}\tau.
If this integral converges uniformly at each limit for all sufficiently large t , then by the Riemann–Lebesgue lemma (§LABEL:sec:AL.FS.de)
q(t)=f(t)+o\left(e^{ct}\right), subject to t\to+\infty.

If, in addition, the corresponding integrals with Q and F replaced by their derivatives Q^{(j)} and F^{(j)} , j=1,2,\dots,m , converge uniformly, then by repeated integrations by parts q(t)=f(t)+o\left(t^{-m}e^{ct}\right), subject to t\to+\infty.
The most successful results are obtained on moving the integration contour as far to the left as possible.
For examples see ( , pp. 315–320) .

Let \mathscr{P} denote the path for the contour integral I(z)=\int_{a}^{b}e^{-zp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t, in which a is finite, b is finite or infinite, and \omega is the angle of slope of \mathscr{P} at a , that is, \lim(\operatorname{ph}\left(t-a\right)) as t\to a along \mathscr{P}.
Assume that p(t) and q(t) are analytic on an open domain \mathbf{T} that contains \mathscr{P} , with the possible exceptions of t=a and t=b.

Other assumptions are: In a neighborhood of a p(t)=p(a)+\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}p_{s}(t-a)^{s+\mu}, q(t)=\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}q_{s}(t-a)^{s+\lambda-1}, with \Re\lambda>0 , \mu>0 , p_{0}\neq 0 , and the branches of (t-a)^{\lambda} and (t-a)^{\mu} continuous and constructed with \operatorname{ph}\left(t-a\right)\to\omega as t\to a along \mathscr{P}.
z ranges along a ray or over an annular sector \theta_{1}\leq\theta\leq\theta_{2} , |z|\geq Z , where \theta=\operatorname{ph}z , \theta_{2}-\theta_{1}<\pi , and Z>0.
I(z) converges at b absolutely and uniformly with respect to z.

Excluding t=a , \Re\left(e^{i\theta}p(t)-e^{i\theta}p(a)\right) is positive when t\in\mathscr{P} , and is bounded away from zero uniformly with respect to \theta\in[\theta_{1},\theta_{2}] as t\to b along \mathscr{P}.
Then I(z)\sim e^{-zp(a)}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\Gamma\left(\frac{s+\lambda}{\mu}\right) \frac{b_{s}}{z^{(s+\lambda)/\mu}} as z\to\infty in the sector \theta_{1}\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\theta_{2}.
The coefficients b_{s} are determined as in §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.LM, the branch of \operatorname{ph}p_{0} being chosen to satisfy |\theta+\mu\omega+\operatorname{ph}p_{0}|\leq\tfrac{1}{2}\pi.
For examples see ( , Chapter 4) .
For error bounds see ( ) .
Now suppose that in (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.J) the minimum of \Re(zp(t)) on \mathscr{P} occurs at an interior point t_{0}.
Temporarily assume that \theta (=\operatorname{ph}z) is fixed, so that t_{0} is independent of z.

We may subdivide I(z)=\int_{t_{0}}^{b}e^{-zp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t-\int_{t_{0}}^{a}e^{-zp(t)}q(t) \mathrm{d}t, and apply the result of §LABEL:sec:AS.CI.LM to each integral on the right-hand side, the role of the series (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.K) being played by the Taylor series of p(t) and q(t) at t=t_{0}.
If p^{\prime}(t_{0})\neq 0 , then \mu=1 , \lambda is a positive integer, and the two resulting asymptotic expansions are identical.
Thus the right-hand side of (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.N) reduces to the error terms.
However, if p^{\prime}(t_{0})=0 , then \mu\geq 2 and different branches of some of the fractional powers of p_{0} are used for the coefficients b_{s} ; again see §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.LM.
In consequence, theasymptotic expansion obtained from (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.N) is no longer null.
Zeros of p^{\prime}(t) are called saddle points (or cols) owing to the shape of the surface |p(t)| , t\in\mathbb{C} , in their vicinity.

Cases in which p^{\prime}(t_{0})\neq 0 are usually handled by deforming the integration path in such a way that the minimum of \Re(zp(t)) is attained at a saddle point or at an endpoint. Additionally, it may be advantageous to arrange that \Im(zp(t)) is constant on the path: this will usually lead to greater regions of validity and sharper error bounds.
Paths on which \Im(zp(t)) is constant are also the ones on which |\exp\left(-zp(t)\right)| decreases most rapidly.
For this reason the name method of steepest descents is often used. However, for the purpose of simply deriving the asymptotic expansions the use of steepest descent paths is not essential.
In the commonest case the interior minimum t_{0} of \Re(zp(t)) is a simple zero of p^{\prime}(t).

The final expansion then has the form \int_{a}^{b}e^{-zp(t)}q(t)\mathrm{d}t\sim 2e^{-zp(t_{0})}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty} \Gamma\left(s+\tfrac{1}{2}\right)\frac{b_{2s}}{z^{s+(1/2)}}, in which b_{0}=\dfrac{q}{(2p^{\prime\prime})^{1/2}}, b_{2}=\left(2q^{\prime\prime}-\frac{2p^{\prime\prime\prime}q^{\prime}}{p^{ \prime\prime}}+\left(\frac{5(p^{\prime\prime\prime})^{2}}{6(p^{\prime\prime})^ {2}}-\frac{p^{\mathrm{iv}}}{2p^{\prime\prime}}\right)q\right)\frac{1}{(2p^{ \prime\prime})^{3/2}}, with p,q and their derivatives evaluated at t_{0}.

The branch of \omega_{0}=\operatorname{ph}\left(p^{\prime\prime}(t_{0})\right) is the one satisfying |\theta+2\omega+\omega_{0}|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi , where \omega is the limiting value of \operatorname{ph}\left(t-t_{0}\right) as t\to t_{0} from b.
Higher coefficients b_{2s} in (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.O) can be found from(LABEL:eq:AS.IRV.P1) with \lambda=1 , \mu=2 , and s replaced by 2s.
For integral representations of the b_{2s} and their asymptotic behavior as s\to\infty see ( ) .
The last reference also includes examples, as do ( , Chapter 4) , ( , Chapter 2) , and ( , Chapter 7) .

para.sentence: Consider the integral I(\alpha,z)=\int_{\mathscr{P}}e^{-zp(\alpha,t)}q(\alpha,t)\mathrm{d}t in which z is a large real or complex parameter, p(\alpha,t) and q(\alpha,t) are analytic functions of t and continuous in t and a second parameter \alpha.
Suppose that on the integration path \mathscr{P} there are two simple zeros of \ifrac{\partial p(\alpha,t)}{\partial t} that coincide for a certain value \widehat{\alpha} of \alpha.

The problem of obtaining an asymptotic approximation to I(\alpha,z) that is uniform with respect to \alpha in a region containing \widehat{\alpha} is similar to the problem of a coalescing endpoint and saddle point outlined in §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.CPE.

The change of integration variable is given by p(\alpha,t)=\tfrac{1}{3}w^{3}+aw^{2}+bw+c, with a and b chosen so that the zeros of \ifrac{\partial p(\alpha,t)}{\partial t} correspond to the zeros w_{1}(\alpha),w_{2}(\alpha) , say, of the quadratic w^{2}+2aw+b.

Then I(\alpha,z)=e^{-cz}\int_{\mathscr{Q}}\exp\left(-z\left(\tfrac{1}{3}w^{3}+aw^{2 }+bw\right)\right)f(\alpha,w)\mathrm{d}w, where \mathscr{Q} is the w -map of \mathscr{P} , and f(\alpha,w)=q(\alpha,t)\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\mathrm{d}w}=q(\alpha,t)\frac{w^{2}+ 2aw+b}{\ifrac{\partial p(\alpha,t)}{\partial t}}.
The function f(\alpha,w) is analytic at w=w_{1}(\alpha) and w=w_{2}(\alpha) when \alpha\neq\widehat{\alpha} , and at the confluence of these points when \alpha=\widehat{\alpha}.
For large |z| , I(\alpha,z) is approximated uniformly by the integral that corresponds to (LABEL:eq:AS.CI.S) when f(\alpha,w) is replaced by a constant.

By making a further change of variable w=z^{-1/3}v-a, and assigning an appropriate value to c to modify the contour, the approximating integral is reducible to an Airy function or a Scorer function (§§LABEL:sec:AI.DE, LABEL:sec:AI.SC).
For examples, proofs, and extensions see ( , Chapter 9) , ( , Chapter 7) , ( ) , ( ) , ( , Chapter 9) , and ( ) .
For a symbolic method for evaluating the coefficients in the asymptotic expansions see ( ) .

The problems sketched in §§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.CPE and LABEL:sec:AS.CI.CSP involve only two of many possibilities for the coalescence of endpoints, saddle points, and singularities in integrals associated with the special functions.
For a coalescing saddle point and a pole see ( , Chapter 7) and ( ) ; in this case the uniform approximants are complementary error functions.

For a coalescing saddle point and endpoint see ( , Chapter 9) and ( , Chapter 7) ; if the endpoint is an algebraic singularity then the uniform approximants are parabolic cylinder functions with fixed parameter, and if the endpoint is not a singularity then the uniform approximants are complementary error functions.

Let f(t) be a locally integrable function on (0,\infty) , that is, \int_{\rho}^{T}f(t)\mathrm{d}t exists for all \rho and T satisfying 0<\rho<T<\infty.
The Mellin transform of f(t) is defined by \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{z-1}f (t)\mathrm{d}t, when this integral converges.
The domain of analyticity of \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is usually an infinite strip a<\Re z<b parallel to the imaginary axis.
The inversion formula is given by f(t)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}t^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)\mathrm{d}z, with a<c<b.

One of the two convolution integrals associated with the Mellin transform is of the form I(x)=\int_{0}^{\infty}f(t)\,h(xt)\mathrm{d}t, subject to x>0, and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu I\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right).

If \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) have a common strip of analyticity a<\Re z<b , then I(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{c-i\infty}^{c+i\infty}x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\mathrm{d}z, where a<c<b.
When x=1 , this identity is a Parseval-type formula; compare §LABEL:sec:AL.IT.ml.

If \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to meromorphic functions in a left half-plane, and if the contour \Re z=c can be translated to \Re z=d with d<c , then I(x)=\sum\limits_{d<\Re z<c}\Residue\left[x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f \mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\right]+E(x), where E(x)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{d-i\infty}^{d+i\infty}x^{-z}\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right)\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z \right)\mathrm{d}z.

Similarly, if \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to meromorphic functions in a right half-plane, and if the vertical line of integration can be translated to the right, then we obtain an asymptotic expansion for I(x) for large values of x.

subsection.title: Extensions

para.sentence: Let f(t) and h(t) be locally integrable on (0,\infty) and f(t)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}t^{\alpha_{s}}, subject to t\to 0+, where \Re\alpha_{s}>\Re\alpha_{s^{\prime}} for s>s^{\prime} , and \Re\alpha_{s}\to+\infty as s\to\infty.

Also, let h(t)\sim\exp\left(i\kappa t^{p}\right)\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}b_{s}t^{-\beta_{s}}, subject to t\to+\infty, where \kappa is real, p>0 , \Re\beta_{s}>\Re\beta_{s^{\prime}} for s>s^{\prime} , and \Re\beta_{s}\to+\infty as s\to\infty.

To ensure that the integral (LABEL:eq:AS.MTM.C) converges we assume that f(t)=O\left(t^{-b}\right), subject to t\to+\infty, with b+\Re\beta_{0}>1 , and h(t)=O\left(t^{c}\right), subject to t\to 0+, with c+\Re\alpha_{0}>-1.

To apply the Mellin transform method outlined in §LABEL:sec:AS.MTM.I, we require the transforms \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(1-z\right) and \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) to have a common strip of analyticity.
This, in turn, requires -b<\Re\alpha_{0} , -c<\Re\beta_{0} , and either -c<\Re\alpha_{0}+1 or 1-b<\Re\beta_{0}.
Following ( ) we now give an extension of this method in which none of these conditions is required.
First, we introduce the truncated functions f_{1}(t) and f_{2}(t) defined by f_{1}(t)=\begin{cases}f(t),&0<t\leq 1,\\ 0,&1<t<\infty,\end{cases} , f_{2}(t)=f(t)-f_{1}(t).
Similarly, h_{1}(t)=\begin{cases}h(t),&0<t\leq 1,\\ 0,&1<t<\infty,\end{cases} , h_{2}(t)=h(t)-h_{1}(t).

With these definitions and the conditions (LABEL:eq:AS.MTM.N)–(LABEL:eq:AS.MTM.R) the Mellin transforms converge absolutely and define analytic functions in the half-planes shown in Table LABEL:tab:AS.MTM.W.

Similarly, if \kappa=0 in (LABEL:eq:AS.MTM.O), then \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) can be continued analytically to a meromorphic function on the entire z -plane with simple poles at \beta_{s} , s=0,1,2,\dots , with principal part -b_{s}/\left(z-\beta_{s}\right).

Since \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) is analytic for \Re z>-c by Table LABEL:tab:AS.MTM.W, the analytically-continued \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) allows us to extend the Mellin transform of h via \mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h _{1}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)+\mathscr{M}\mskip-3.0mu h_{2}\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) in the same half-plane.

Let f(t) be locally integrable on [0,\infty).
The Stieltjes transform of f(t) is defined by \mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right)=\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{f( t)}{t+z}\mathrm{d}t.

To derive an asymptotic expansion of \mathcal{S}\mskip-3.0mu f\mskip 3.0mu \left(z\right) for large values of |z| , with |\operatorname{ph}z|<\pi , we assume that f(t) possesses an asymptotic expansion of the form f(t)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}a_{s}t^{-s-\alpha}, subject to t\to+\infty, with 0<\alpha\leq 1.
For each n=1,2,3,\dots , set f(t)=\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}a_{s}t^{-s-\alpha}+f_{n}(t).
To each function in this equation, we shall assign a tempered distribution (i.e., a continuous linear functional) on the space \mathcal{T} of rapidly decreasing functions on \mathbb{R}.
Since f(t) is locally integrable on [0,\infty) , it defines a distribution by \left\langle f,\phi\right\rangle=\int_{0}^{\infty}f(t)\phi(t)\mathrm{d}t, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}.
In particular, \left\langle t^{-\alpha},\phi\right\rangle=\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{-\alpha}\phi(t) \mathrm{d}t, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}, when 0<\alpha<1.
Since the functions t^{-s-\alpha} , s=1,2,\dots , are not locally integrable on [0,\infty) , we cannot assign distributions to them in a similar manner.
However, they are multiples of the derivatives of t^{-\alpha}.

Motivated by the definition of distributional derivatives, we can assign them the distributions defined by \left\langle t^{-s-\alpha},\phi\right\rangle=\frac{1}{{\left(\alpha\right)_{s} }}\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{-\alpha}\phi^{(s)}(t)\mathrm{d}t, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}, where {\left(\alpha\right)_{s}}=\alpha(\alpha+1)\cdots(\alpha+s-1).
Similarly, in the case \alpha=1 , we define \left\langle t^{-s-1},\phi\right\rangle=-\frac{1}{s!}\int_{0}^{\infty}(\ln t) \phi^{(s+1)}(t)\mathrm{d}t, subject to \phi\in\mathcal{T}.

To assign a distribution to the function f_{n}(t) , we first let f_{n,n}(t) denote the n th repeated integral (§LABEL:sec:AL.COO.di) of f_{n} : f_{n,n}(t)=\frac{(-1)^{n}}{(n-1)!}\int_{t}^{\infty}(\tau-t)^{n-1}f_{n}(\tau) \mathrm{d}\tau.
For 0<\alpha<1 , it is easily seen that f_{n,n}(t) is bounded on [0,R] for any positive constant R , and is O\left(t^{-\alpha}\right) as t\to\infty.
For \alpha=1 , we have f_{n,n}(t)=O\left(t^{-1}\right) as t\to\infty and f_{n,n}(t)=O\left(\ln t\right) as t\to 0+.

Thus a regular singularity has rank 0. The most common type of irregular singularity for special functions has rank 1 and is located at infinity.
Then f(z)=\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{f_{s}}{z^{s}}, g(z)=\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{g_{s}}{z^{s}}, these series converging in an annulus |z|>a , with at least one of f_{0} , g_{0} , g_{1} nonzero.

Formal solutions are e^{\lambda_{j}z}z^{\mu_{j}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{s,j}}{z^{s}}, subject to j=1,2, where \lambda_{1} , \lambda_{2} are the roots of the characteristic equation \lambda^{2}+f_{0}\lambda+g_{0}=0, \mu_{j}=-(f_{1}\lambda_{j}+g_{1})/(f_{0}+2\lambda_{j}), a_{0,j}=1 , and (f_{0}+2\lambda_{j})sa_{s,j}=(s-\mu_{j})(s-1-\mu_{j})a_{s-1,j}+\sum_{r=1}^{s} \left(\lambda_{j}f_{r+1}+g_{r+1}-(s-r-\mu_{j})f_{r}\right)a_{s-r,j}, when s=1,2,\dots.

For irregular singularities of nonclassifiable rank, a powerful tool for finding the asymptotic behavior of solutions, complete with error bounds, is as follows:
In a finite or infinite interval (a_{1},a_{2}) let f(x) be real, positive, and twice-continuously differentiable, and g(x) be continuous.

Then in (a_{1},a_{2}) the differential equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{2}}=(f(x)+g(x))w has twice-continuously differentiable solutions w_{1}(x)=f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right)\*\left(1+ \epsilon_{1}(x)\right), , w_{2}(x)=f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(-\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right)\*\left(1+ \epsilon_{2}(x)\right), such that |\epsilon_{j}(x)|,\;\;\tfrac{1}{2}f^{-1/2}(x)|\epsilon_{j}^{\prime}(x)|\leq \exp\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\mathcal{V}_{a_{j},x}\left(F\right)\right)-1, subject to j=1,2, provided that \mathcal{V}_{a_{j},x}\left(F\right)<\infty.

Here F(x) is theerror-control function F(x)=\int\left(\frac{1}{f^{1/4}}\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{2}} \left(\frac{1}{f^{1/4}}\right)-\frac{g}{f^{1/2}}\right)\mathrm{d}x, and \mathcal{V} denotes the variational operator (§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.IP).

Thus \mathcal{V}_{a_{j},x}\left(F\right)=\int_{a_{j}}^{x}\left|\left(\frac{1}{f^{1/ 4}(t)}\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}t}^{2}}\left(\frac{1}{f^{1/4}(t)} \right)-\frac{g(t)}{f^{1/2}(t)}\right)\mathrm{d}t\right|.

Assuming also \mathcal{V}_{a_{1},a_{2}}\left(F\right)<\infty , we have w_{1}(x)\sim f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right), subject to x\to a_{1}+, w_{2}(x)\sim f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(-\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right), subject to x\to a_{2}-.
Suppose in addition |\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x| is unbounded as x\to a_{1}+ and x\to a_{2}-.

Then there are solutions w_{3}(x) , w_{4}(x) , such that w_{3}(x)\sim f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right), subject to x\to a_{2}-, w_{4}(x)\sim f^{-1/4}(x)\exp\left(-\int f^{1/2}(x)\mathrm{d}x\right), subject to x\to a_{1}+.
The solutions with the properties (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.Y), (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.Z) are unique, but not those with the properties (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.AA), (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.BB).
In fact, since w_{1}(x)/w_{4}(x)\to 0, subject to x\to a_{1}+, w_{1}(x) is a recessive (or subdominant) solution as x\to a_{1}+ , and w_{4}(x) is a dominant solution as x\to a_{1}+.
Similarly for w_{2}(x) and w_{3}(x) as x\to a_{2}-.
\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{2}}=(x+\ln x)w, subject to 0<x<\infty.
We cannot take f=x and g=\ln x because \int gf^{-1/2}\mathrm{d}x would diverge as x\to+\infty.
Instead set f=x+\ln x , g=0.

By approximating f^{1/2}=x^{1/2}+\tfrac{1}{2}x^{-1/2}\ln x+O\left(x^{-3/2}(\ln x)^{2}\right), we arrive at w_{2}(x)\sim x^{-(1/4)-\sqrt{x}}\exp\left(2x^{1/2}-\tfrac{2}{3}x^{3/2}\right), , w_{3}(x)\sim x^{-(1/4)+\sqrt{x}}\exp\left(\tfrac{2}{3}x^{3/2}-2x^{1/2}\right), as x\to+\infty , w_{2}(x) being recessive and w_{3}(x) dominant.

One pair of independent solutions of the equation \ifrac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=w is w_{1}(z)=e^{z} , w_{2}(z)=e^{-z}.
Another is w_{3}(z)=\cosh z , w_{4}(z)=\sinh z.
In theory either pair may be used to construct any other solution w(z)=Aw_{1}(z)+Bw_{2}(z), or w(z)=Cw_{3}(z)+Dw_{4}(z), where A,B,C,D are constants.

From the numerical standpoint, however, the pair w_{3}(z) and w_{4}(z) has the drawback that severe numerical cancellation can occur with certain combinations of C and D , for example if C and D are equal, or nearly equal, and z , or \Re z , is large and negative.
This kind of cancellation cannot take place with w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) , and for this reason, and following ( ) , we call w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) anumerically satisfactory pair of solutions.
The solutions w_{1}(z) and w_{2}(z) are respectively recessive and dominant as \Re z\to-\infty , and vice versa as \Re z\to+\infty.
This is characteristic of numerically satisfactory pairs.
In a neighborhood, or sectorial neighborhood of a singularity, one member has to be recessive.

In consequence, if a differential equation has more than one singularity in the extended plane, then usually more than two standard solutions need to be chosen in order to have numerically satisfactory representations everywhere.
In oscillatory intervals, and again following ( ) , we call a pair of solutions numerically satisfactory if asymptotically they have the same amplitude and are \tfrac{1}{2}\pi out of phase.

Many special functions satisfy an equation of the form \ifrac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=\left(u^{2}f(z)+g(z)\right)w, in which u is a real or complex parameter, and asymptotic solutions are needed for large |u| that are uniform with respect to z in a point set \mathbf{D} in \mathbb{R} or \mathbb{C}.
For example, u can be the order of a Bessel function or degree of an orthogonal polynomial.
The form of the asymptotic expansion depends on the nature of the transition points in \mathbf{D} , that is, points at which f(z) has a zero or singularity.
Zeros of f(z) are alsocalled turning points.
There are three main cases.
In Case I there are no transition points in \mathbf{D} and g(z) is analytic.
In Case II f(z) has a simple zero at z_{0} and g(z) is analytic at z_{0}.
In Case III f(z) has a simple pole at z_{0} and (z-z_{0})^{2}g(z) is analytic at z_{0}.
The same approach is used in all three cases.
First we apply theLiouville transformation (§LABEL:sec:AL.DE.cv) to (LABEL:eq:AS.DEWP.A).
This introduces new variables W and \xi , related by W=\dot{z}^{-1/2}w, dots denoting differentiations with respect to \xi.

Then \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\xi}^{2}}=\left(u^{2}\dot{z}^{2}f(z)+\psi( \xi)\right)W, where \psi(\xi)=\dot{z}^{2}g(z)+\dot{z}^{1/2}\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}\xi} ^{2}}(\dot{z}^{-1/2}).

The transformation is now specialized in such a way that: (a) \xi and z are analytic functions of each other at the transition point (if any); (b) the approximating differential equation obtained by neglecting \psi(\xi) (or part of \psi(\xi) ) has solutions that are functions of a single variable.

The actual choices are as follows: \dot{z}^{2}f(z)=1, \xi=\int f^{1/2}(z)\mathrm{d}z, for Case I, \dot{z}^{2}f(z)=\xi, \tfrac{2}{3}\xi^{3/2}=\int_{z_{0}}^{z}f^{1/2}(t)\mathrm{d}t, for Case II, \dot{z}^{2}f(z)=1/\xi, 2\xi^{1/2}=\int_{z_{0}}^{z}f^{1/2}(t)\mathrm{d}t, for Case III.
The transformed equation has the form \ifrac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\xi}^{2}}=\left(u^{2}\xi^{m}+\psi(\xi) \right)W, with m=0 (Case I), m=1 (Case II), m=-1 (Case III).
In Cases I and II the asymptotic solutions are in terms of the functions that satisfy(LABEL:eq:AS.DEWP.E) with \psi(\xi)=0.
These are elementary functions in Case I, and Airy functions (§LABEL:sec:AI.DE) in Case II.
In Case III the approximating equation is \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}W}{{\mathrm{d}\xi}^{2}}=\left(\frac{u^{2}}{\xi}+\frac{ \rho}{\xi^{2}}\right)W, where \rho=\lim(\xi^{2}\psi(\xi)) as \xi\to 0.
Solutions are Bessel functions, or modified Bessel functions, of order \pm(1+4\rho)^{1/2} (§§LABEL:sec:BS.DEF, LABEL:sec:BS.MDEF).

More generally, g(z) can have a simple or double pole at z_{0}.
(In the case of the double pole the order of the approximating Bessel functions is fixed but no longer 1/(\lambda+2).
) However, in all cases with \lambda>-2 and \lambda\neq 0 or \pm 1 , only uniform asymptotic approximations are available, not uniform asymptotic expansions.
For results, including error bounds, see ( ) .
For connection formulas for Liouville–Green approximations across these transition points see ( ) .
Corresponding to the problems for integrals outlined in §§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.CPE, LABEL:sec:AS.CI.CSP, and LABEL:sec:AS.CI.OCCP, there are analogous problems for differential equations.
For two coalescing turning points see ( ) and ( ) ; in this case the uniform approximants are parabolic cylinder functions.
(For envelope functions for parabolic cylinder functions see §LABEL:sec:LE.UAA.LDO).
For a coalescing turning point and double pole see ( ) and ( ) ; in this case the uniform approximants are Bessel functions of variable order.
For a coalescing turning point and simple pole see ( ) and ( ) ; in this case the uniform approximants are Whittaker functions (§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH) with a fixed value of the second parameter.

For further examples of uniform asymptotic approximations in terms of parabolic cylinder functions see §§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.AS.MU.PC, LABEL:sec:CH.KM.AS.MU.PC2,LABEL:sec:LE.UAA.LDO, LABEL:sec:HY.AS.LP, LABEL:sec:OP.AS.AE.

For further examples of uniform asymptotic approximations in terms of Bessel functions or modified Bessel functions of variable order see §§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.AS.KA.BS, LABEL:sec:LE.UAA.LOSMD, LABEL:sec:LE.UAA.LDSMO,LABEL:sec:LE.CMF.AA2, LABEL:sec:SW.AE.PR, LABEL:sec:SW.AE.OB.
For examples of uniform asymptotic approximations in terms of Whittaker functions with fixed second parameter see §LABEL:sec:OP.AA.Ja and §LABEL:sec:MA.AQ.BEX.
Lastly, for an example of a fourth-order differential equation, see ( ) .

Many special functions that depend on parameters satisfy a three-term linear recurrence relation {w(n+2)+f(n)w(n+1)+g(n)w(n)=0}, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, or equivalently the second-order homogeneous linear difference equation \Delta^{2}w(n)+(2+f(n))\Delta w(n)+(1+f(n)+g(n))w(n)=0, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, in which \Delta is the forward difference operator (§LABEL:sec:NM.LDE.I).
Often f(n) and g(n) can be expanded in series f(n)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{f_{s}}{n^{s}}, g(n)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{g_{s}}{n^{s}} subject to n\to\infty, with g_{0}\neq 0.

(For the case g_{0}=0 see the final paragraph of §LABEL:sec:AS.DE2.CCV with Q negative.)This situation is analogous to second-order homogeneous linear differential equations with an irregular singularity of rank 1 at infinity (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.IS).

Formal solutions are \rho_{j}^{n}n^{\alpha_{j}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{s,j}}{n^{s}}, subject to j=1,2, where \rho_{1},\rho_{2} are the roots of the characteristic equation \rho^{2}+f_{0}\rho+g_{0}=0, \alpha_{j}=(f_{1}\rho_{j}+g_{1})/(f_{0}\rho_{j}+2g_{0}), a_{0,j}=1 , and
The construction fails if \rho_{1}=\rho_{2} , that is, when f_{0}^{2}=4g_{0}.

When f_{0}^{2}\neq 4g_{0} , there are linearly independent solutions w_{j}(n) , j=1,2 , such that w_{j}(n)\sim\rho_{j}^{n}n^{\alpha_{j}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{s,j}}{n^{s}}, subject to n\to\infty.
If |\rho_{2}|>|\rho_{1}| , or if |\rho_{2}|=|\rho_{1}| and \Re\alpha_{2}>\Re\alpha_{1} , then w_{1}(n) is recessive and w_{2}(n) is dominant as n\to\infty.

As in the case of differential equations (§§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.LGA, LABEL:sec:AS.DE.NSS) recessive solutions are unique and dominant solutions are not; furthermore, one member of a numerically satisfactory pair has to be recessive.
When |\rho_{2}|=|\rho_{1}| and \Re\alpha_{2}=\Re\alpha_{1} neither solution is dominant and both are unique.
For proofs see ( ) .
For error bounds see ( ) .
See also ( ) .
For asymptotic expansions in inverse factorial series see ( ) .
When the roots of (LABEL:eq:AS.DE2.E) are equal we denote them both by \rho.
Assume first 2g_{1}\neq f_{0}f_{1}.

Then (LABEL:eq:AS.DE2.A) has independent solutions w_{j}(n) , j=1,2 , such that w_{j}(n)\sim\rho^{n}\exp\left((-1)^{j}\kappa\sqrt{n}\right)n^{\alpha}\sum_{s=0 }^{\infty}(-1)^{js}\frac{c_{s}}{n^{s/2}}, where \sqrt{g_{0}}\kappa=\sqrt{2f_{0}f_{1}-4g_{1}}, subject to 4g_{0}\alpha=g_{0}+2g_{1}, c_{0}=1 , and higher coefficients are determined by formal substitution.
Alternatively, suppose that 2g_{1}=f_{0}f_{1}.
Then the indices \alpha_{1},\alpha_{2} are the roots of 2g_{0}\alpha^{2}-(f_{0}f_{1}+2g_{0})\alpha+2g_{2}-f_{0}f_{2}=0.

Provided that \alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1} is not zero or an integer, (LABEL:eq:AS.DE2.A) has independent solutions w_{j}(n) , j=1,2 , of the form w_{j}(n)\sim\rho^{n}n^{\alpha_{j}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{s,j}}{n^{s}}, subject to n\to\infty, with a_{0,j}=1 and higher coefficients given by (LABEL:eq:AS.DE2.G) (in the present case the coefficients of a_{s,j} and a_{s-1,j} are zero).
If \alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}=0,1,2,\dots , then (LABEL:eq:AS.DE2.L) applies only in the case j=1.

But there is an independent solution w_{2}(n)\sim\rho^{n}n^{\alpha_{2}}\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}s=0\\ s\neq\alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}\end{subarray}}^{\infty}\frac{b_{s}}{n^{s}}+cw_{1}(n )\ln n, subject to n\to\infty.
The coefficients b_{s} and constant c are again determined by formal substitution, beginning with c=1 when \alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}=0 , or with b_{0}=1 when \alpha_{2}-\alpha_{1}=1,2,3,\dots.
(Compare (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.F).)
For proofs and examples, see ( ) .
For error bounds see ( ) .
For analogous results for difference equations of the form w(n+2)+n^{P}f(n)w(n+1)+n^{Q}g(n)w(n)=0, in which P and Q are any integers see ( ) .

For asymptotic approximations to solutions of second-order difference equations analogous to the Liouville–Green (WKBJ) approximation for differential equations (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.LGA) see ( ) and ( ) .
Error bounds and applicationsare included.
For discussions of turning points, transition points, and uniform asymptotic expansions for solutions of linear difference equations of the second order see ( ) .
For an introduction to, and references for, the general asymptotic theory of linear difference equations of arbitrary order, see ( , Appendix B) .
For applications of asymptotic methods for difference equations to orthogonal polynomials, see, e.g. ( ) and ( ) .
These methods are particularly useful when the weight function associated with the orthogonal polynomials is not unique or not even known; see, e.g. ( ) .

As in §LABEL:sec:BP.DE, let B_{n} and B_{n}\left(x\right) denote the n th Bernoulli number and polynomial, respectively, and \widetilde{B}_{n}\left(x\right) the n th Bernoulli periodic function B_{n}\left(x-\left\lfloor x\right\rfloor\right).
Assume that a,m , and n are integers such that n>a , m>0 , and f^{(2m)}(x) is absolutely integrable over [a,n].

Then \sum_{j=a}^{n}f(j)=\int_{a}^{n}f(x)\mathrm{d}x+\tfrac{1}{2}f(a)+\tfrac{1}{2}f( n)+\sum_{s=1}^{m-1}\frac{B_{2s}}{(2s)!}\left(f^{(2s-1)}(n)-f^{(2s-1)}(a)\right )+\int_{a}^{n}\frac{B_{2m}-\widetilde{B}_{2m}\left(x\right)}{(2m)!}f^{(2m)}(x) \mathrm{d}x.
This is the Euler–Maclaurin formula.

Another version is theAbel–Plana formula: \sum_{j=a}^{n}f(j)=\int_{a}^{n}f(x)\mathrm{d}x+\tfrac{1}{2}f(a)+\tfrac{1}{2}f( n)-2\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\Im(f(a+iy))}{e^{2\pi y}-1}\mathrm{d}y+\sum_{s=1}^{ m}\frac{B_{2s}}{(2s)!}f^{(2s-1)}(n)+2\frac{(-1)^{m}}{(2m)!}\int_{0}^{\infty} \Im(f^{(2m)}(n+i\vartheta_{n}y))\frac{y^{2m}\mathrm{d}y}{e^{2\pi y}-1}, \vartheta_{n} being some number in the interval (0,1).

Sufficient conditions for the validity of this second result are: On the strip a\leq\Re z\leq n , f(z) is analytic in its interior, f^{(2m)}(z) is continuous on its closure, and f(z)=o\left(e^{2\pi|\Im z|}\right) as \Im z\to\pm\infty , uniformly with respect to \Re z\in[a,n].
f(z) is real when a\leq z\leq n.
The first infinite integral in (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.B) converges.
S(n)=\sum_{j=1}^{n}j\ln j for large n.

From (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.A) S(n)=\tfrac{1}{2}n^{2}\ln n-\tfrac{1}{4}n^{2}+\tfrac{1}{2}n\ln n+\tfrac{1}{12} \ln n+C+\sum_{s=2}^{m-1}\frac{(-B_{2s})}{2s(2s-1)(2s-2)}\frac{1}{n^{2s-2}}+R_{ m}(n), where m ( \geq 2 ) is arbitrary, C is a constant, and R_{m}(n)=\int_{n}^{\infty}\frac{\widetilde{B}_{2m}\left(x\right)-B_{2m}}{2m(2m -1)x^{2m-1}}\mathrm{d}x.
From §LABEL:sec:BP.ZE.BE, (LABEL:eq:BP.DE.SIB), and (LABEL:eq:BP.EL.SPB2), \widetilde{B}_{2m}\left(x\right)-B_{2m} isof constant sign (-1)^{m}.

Thus R_{m}(n) and R_{m+1}(n) are of opposite signs, and since their difference is the term corresponding to s=m in (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.D), R_{m}(n) is bounded in absolute value by this term and has the same sign.
Formula (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.B) is useful for evaluating the constant term in expansions obtained from (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.A).

In the present example it leads to C=\frac{\gamma+\ln\left(2\pi\right)}{12}-\frac{\zeta'\left(2\right)}{2\pi^{2}} =\frac{1}{12}-\zeta'\left(-1\right), where \gamma is Euler’s constant (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def.EC) and \zeta' is the derivative of the Riemann zeta function (§LABEL:sec:ZE.Def.Def).
e^{C} is sometimes called Glaisher’s constant.
For further information on C see §LABEL:sec:GA.DGF.

Other examples that can be verified in a similar way are: \sum_{j=1}^{n-1}j^{\alpha}\sim\zeta\left(-\alpha\right)+\frac{n^{\alpha+1}}{ \alpha+1}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{\alpha+1}{s}\frac{B_{s}}{n ^{s}}, subject to n\to\infty, where \alpha ( \neq-1 ) is a real constant, and \sum_{j=1}^{n-1}\frac{1}{j}\sim\ln n+\gamma-\frac{1}{2n}-\sum_{s=1}^{\infty} \frac{B_{2s}}{2s}\frac{1}{n^{2s}}, subject to n\to\infty.

In both expansions the remainder term is bounded in absolute value by the first neglected term in the sum, and has the same sign, provided that in the case of (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.G), truncation takes place at s=2m-1 , where m is any positive integer satisfying m\geq\frac{1}{2}(\alpha+1).
For extensions of the Euler–Maclaurin formula to functions f(x) with singularities at x=a or x=n (or both) see ( ) .See also ( ) .
For an extension to integrals with Cauchy principal values see ( ) .
The formula for summation by parts is \sum_{j=1}^{n-1}u_{j}v_{j}=U_{n-1}v_{n}+\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}U_{j}(v_{j}-v_{j+1}), where U_{j}=u_{1}+u_{2}+\dots+u_{j}.

This identity can be used to find asymptotic approximations for large n when the factor v_{j} changes slowly with j , and u_{j} is oscillatory; compare the approximation of Fourier integrals by integration by parts in §LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.IP.
S(\alpha,\beta,n)=\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}e^{ij\beta}j^{\alpha}, where \alpha and \beta are real constants with e^{i\beta}\neq 1.

As a first estimate for large n |S(\alpha,\beta,n)|\leq\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}j^{\alpha}=O\left(1\right),\;O\left(\ln n \right),\text{ or }O\left(n^{\alpha+1}\right), according as \alpha<-1 , \alpha=-1 , or \alpha>-1; see (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.G), (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.H).

With u_{j}=e^{ij\beta} , v_{j}=j^{\alpha} , U_{j}=e^{i\beta}(e^{ij\beta}-1)/(e^{i\beta}-1), and S(\alpha,\beta,n)=\frac{e^{i\beta}}{e^{i\beta}-1}\left(e^{i(n-1)\beta}n^{ \alpha}-1+\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}e^{ij\beta}\left(j^{\alpha}-(j+1)^{\alpha}\right) \right).

Since j^{\alpha}-(j+1)^{\alpha}=-\alpha j^{\alpha-1}+\alpha(\alpha-1)O\left(j^{ \alpha-2}\right) for any real constant \alpha and the set of all positive integers j , we derive S(\alpha,\beta,n)=\frac{e^{i\beta}}{e^{i\beta}-1}\left(e^{i(n-1)\beta}n^{ \alpha}-\alpha S(\alpha-1,\beta,n)+O\left(n^{\alpha-1}\right)+O\left(1\right) \right).
From this result and (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.L) S(\alpha,\beta,n)=O\left(n^{\alpha}\right)+O\left(1\right).

Then replacing \alpha by \alpha-1 and resubstituting in (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.P), we have S(\alpha,\beta,n)=\frac{e^{in\beta}}{e^{i\beta}-1}n^{\alpha}+O\left(n^{\alpha- 1}\right)+O\left(1\right), subject to n\to\infty, which is a useful approximation when \alpha>0.
For extensions to \alpha\leq 0 , higher terms, and other examples, see ( , Chapter 8) .

The asymptotic behavior of entire functions defined by Maclaurin series can be approached by converting the sum into a contour integral by use of the residue theorem and applying the methods of §§LABEL:sec:AS.CI and LABEL:sec:AS.MTM.
From §§LABEL:sec:GH.DF.GHS–LABEL:sec:GH.DF.PLEQ {{}_{0}F_{2}}\left(-;1,1;x\right)=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{j}}{(j!)^{3}}.
We seek the behavior as x\to+\infty.
From (LABEL:eq:AL.FC.rt.1)

\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}\frac{x^{j}}{(j!)^{3}}=\frac{1}{2i}\int_{\mathscr{C}}\frac{x^{ t}}{(\Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\cot\left(\pi t\right)\mathrm{d}t, where \mathscr{C} comprises the two semicircles and two parts of the imaginary axis depicted in Figure LABEL:fig:AS.SS.A.

From the identities \frac{\cot\left(\pi t\right)}{2i}=-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{e^{-2\pi it}-1}=\frac{ 1}{2}+\frac{1}{e^{2\pi it}-1}, and Cauchy’s theorem, we have \sum_{j=0}^{n-1}\frac{x^{j}}{(j!)^{3}}=\int_{-1/2}^{n-(1/2)}\frac{x^{t}}{( \Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\mathrm{d}t-\int_{\mathscr{C}_{1}}\frac{x^{t}}{( \Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{e^{-2\pi it}-1}+\int_{\mathscr{ C}_{2}}\frac{x^{t}}{(\Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{e^{2\pi it }-1}, where \mathscr{C}_{1},\mathscr{C}_{2} denote respectively the upper and lower halves of \mathscr{C}.
(LABEL:eq:GA.AE.PE.5) shows that the integrals around the large quarter circles vanish as n\to\infty.

Hence {{}_{0}F_{2}}\left(-;1,1;x\right)=\int_{-1/2}^{\infty}\frac{x^{t}}{(\Gamma \left(t+1\right))^{3}}\mathrm{d}t+2\Re\int_{-1/2}^{i\infty}\frac{x^{t}}{( \Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{e^{-2\pi it}-1}=\int_{0}^{ \infty}\frac{x^{t}}{(\Gamma\left(t+1\right))^{3}}\mathrm{d}t+O\left(1\right), subject to x\to+\infty, the last step following from |x^{t}|\leq 1 when t is on the interval [-\frac{1}{2},0] , the imaginary axis, or the small semicircle.

By application of Laplace’s method (§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.LM) and use again of (LABEL:eq:GA.AE.PE.5), we obtain {{}_{0}F_{2}}\left(-;1,1;x\right)\sim\frac{\exp\left(3x^{1/3}\right)}{2\pi 3^{ 1/2}x^{1/3}}, subject to x\to+\infty.
For generalizations and other examples see ( , Chapter 8) , ( ) , and ( ) .
See also ( , Chapter 5) and §§LABEL:sec:GH.AS.FOR–LABEL:sec:GH.AS.Z.

subsection.title: Taylor and Laurent Coefficients: Darboux’s Method

para.sentence: Let f(z) be analytic on the annulus 0<|z|<r , with Laurent expansion f(z)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}f_{n}z^{n}, subject to 0<|z|<r.
What is the asymptotic behavior of f_{n} as n\to\infty or n\to-\infty?
More specially, what is the behavior of the higher coefficients in a Taylor-series expansion?

These problems can be brought within the scope of §LABEL:sec:AS.CI by means of Cauchy’s integral formula f_{n}=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\mathscr{C}}\frac{f(z)}{z^{n+1}}\mathrm{d}z, where \mathscr{C} is a simple closed contour in the annulus that encloses z=0.
For examples see ( , Chapters 8, 9) .
However, if r is finite and f(z) has algebraic or logarithmic singularities on |z|=r , then Darboux’s method is usually easier to apply.
We need a “comparison function” g(z) with the properties: g(z) is analytic on 0<|z|<r.
f(z)-g(z) is continuous on 0<|z|\leq r.
The coefficients in the Laurent expansion g(z)=\sum_{n=-\infty}^{\infty}g_{n}z^{n}, subject to 0<|z|<r, have known asymptotic behavior as n\to\pm\infty.

By allowing the contour in Cauchy’s formula to expand, we find that f_{n}-g_{n}=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{|z|=r}\frac{f(z)-g(z)}{z^{n+1}}\mathrm{d}z= \frac{1}{2\pi r^{n}}\int_{0}^{2\pi}\left(f\left(re^{i\theta}\right)-g\left(re^ {i\theta}\right)\right)e^{-ni\theta}\mathrm{d}\theta.
Hence by the Riemann–Lebesgue lemma (§LABEL:sec:AL.FS.de)
f_{n}=g_{n}+o\left(r^{-n}\right), subject to n\to\pm\infty.
This result is refinable in two important ways.
First, the conditions can be weakened. It is unnecessary for f(z)-g(z) to be continuous on |z|=r : it suffices that the integrals in (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.CC) converge uniformly.

For example, Condition (b) can be replaced by: On the circle |z|=r , the function f(z)-g(z) has a finite number of singularities, and at each singularity z_{j} , say, f(z)-g(z)=O\left((z-z_{j})^{\sigma_{j}-1}\right), subject to z\to z_{j}, where \sigma_{j} is a positive constant.

Secondly, when f(z)-g(z) is m times continuously differentiable on |z|=r the result (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.EE) can be strengthened. In these circumstances the integrals in (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.CC) are integrable by parts m times, yielding f_{n}=g_{n}+o\left(r^{-n}|n|^{-m}\right), subject to n\to\pm\infty.

Furthermore, (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.EE2) remains valid with the weaker condition f^{(m)}(z)-g^{(m)}(z)=O\left((z-z_{j})^{\sigma_{j}-1}\right), in the neighborhood of each singularity z_{j} , again with \sigma_{j}>0.
Let \alpha be a constant in (0,2\pi) and P_{n} denote the Legendre polynomial of degree n.
From §LABEL:sec:LE.IDO.GF f(z)=\frac{1}{(1-2z\cos\alpha+z^{2})^{1/2}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}P_{n}\left(\cos \alpha\right)z^{n}, subject to |z|<1.
The singularities of f(z) on the unit circle are branch points at z=e^{\pm i\alpha}.

To match the limiting behavior of f(z) at these points we set g(z)=e^{-\pi i/4}(2\sin\alpha)^{-1/2}\left(e^{-i\alpha}-z\right)^{-1/2}+e^{\pi i /4}(2\sin\alpha)^{-1/2}\left(e^{i\alpha}-z\right)^{-1/2}.
Here the branch of \left(e^{-i\alpha}-z\right)^{-1/2} is continuous in the z -plane cut along the outward-drawn ray through z=e^{-i\alpha} and equals e^{i\alpha/2} at z=0.
Similarly for \left(e^{i\alpha}-z\right)^{-1/2}.

In Condition (c) we have g_{n}=\left(\frac{2}{\pi\sin\alpha}\right)^{1/2}\frac{\Gamma\left(n+\frac{1}{2 }\right)}{n!}\cos\left(n\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}\alpha-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right) , and in the supplementary conditions we may set m=1.
Then from (LABEL:eq:AS.SS.EE2) and (LABEL:eq:GA.AE.PE.5)
P_{n}\left(\cos\alpha\right)=\left(\frac{2}{\pi n\sin\alpha}\right)^{1/2}\cos \left(n\alpha+\tfrac{1}{2}\alpha-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right)+o\left(n^{-1}\right).
For higher terms see §LABEL:sec:OP.AA.Le.
For uniform expansions when two singularities coalesce on the circle of convergence see ( ) .
For other examples and extensions see ( , Chapter 8) , ( ) , ( , Chapter 2) , and ( ) .
See also ( ) .

When a rigorous bound or reliable estimate for the remainder term is unavailable, it is unsafe to judge the accuracy of an asymptotic expansion merely from the numerical rate of decrease of the terms at the point of truncation.
Even when the series converges this is unwise: the tail needs to be majorized rigorously before the result can be guaranteed. For divergent expansions the situation is even more difficult.
First, it is impossible to bound the tail by majorizing its terms.
Secondly, the asymptotic series represents an infinite class of functions, and the remainder depends on which member we have in mind.
As an example consider I(m)=\int_{0}^{\pi}\frac{\cos\left(mt\right)}{t^{2}+1}\mathrm{d}t, with m a large integer.

By integration by parts (§LABEL:sec:AS.IRV.IP) I(m)\sim(-1)^{m}\sum_{s=1}^{\infty}\frac{q_{s}(\pi)}{m^{2s}}, subject to m\to\infty, with q_{1}(t)=-\frac{2t}{(t^{2}+1)^{2}}, q_{2}(t)=\frac{24(t^{3}-t)}{(t^{2}+1)^{4}}, q_{3}(t)=-\frac{240(3t^{5}-10t^{3}+3t)}{(t^{2}+1)^{6}}.

On rounding to 5D, we have q_{1}(\pi)=-0.0531 8, q_{2}(\pi)=0.0479 1, q_{3}(\pi)=-0.0898 5. Taking m=10 in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.B), the first three terms give us the approximation I(10)\approx-0.00053\;18+0.00000\;48-0.00000\;01=-0.00052\;71.
But this answer is incorrect: to 7D I(10)=-0.00045\;5 8. The error term is, in fact, approximately 700 times the last term obtained in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.D).
The explanation is that (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.B) is a more accurate expansion for the function I(m)-\frac{1}{2}\pi e^{-m} than it is for I(m) ; see ( , pp. 76–78) .

In order to guard against this kind of error remaining undetected, the wanted function may need to be computed by another method (preferably nonasymptotic) for the smallest value of the (large) asymptotic variable x that is intended to be used. If the results agree within S significant figures, then it is likely—but not certain—that the truncated asymptotic series will yield at least S correct significant figures for larger values of x.
For further discussion see ( ) .
In \mathbb{C} both the modulus and phase of the asymptotic variable z need to be taken into account.
Suppose an asymptotic expansion holds as z\to\infty in any closed sector within \alpha<\operatorname{ph}z<\beta , say, but not in \alpha\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\beta.

Then numerical accuracy will disintegrate as the boundary rays \operatorname{ph}z=\alpha , \operatorname{ph}z=\beta are approached. In consequence, practical application needs to be confined to a sector \alpha^{\prime}\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\beta^{\prime} well within the sector of validity, and independent evaluations carried out on the boundaries for the smallest value of |z| intended to be used. The choice of \alpha^{\prime} and \beta^{\prime} is facilitated by a knowledge of the relevant Stokes lines; see §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.SP below.

However, regardless whether we can bound the remainder, the accuracy achievable by direct numerical summation of a divergent asymptotic series is always limited. The rest of this section is devoted to general methods for increasing this accuracy.

From §LABEL:sec:IG.GEI.DEF the generalized exponential integral is given by E_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{e^{-z}z^{p-1}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty }\frac{e^{-zt}t^{p-1}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t when \Re p>0 and |\operatorname{ph}z|<\frac{1}{2}\pi , and by analytic continuation for other values of p and z.

Application of Watson’s lemma (§LABEL:sec:AS.CI.WL) yields E_{p}\left(z\right)\sim\frac{e^{-z}}{z}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{{\left (p\right)_{s}}}{z^{s}} when p is fixed and z\to\infty in any closed sector within |\operatorname{ph}z|<\frac{3}{2}\pi.
As noted in §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.NUAE, poor accuracy is yielded by this expansion as \operatorname{ph}z approaches \frac{3}{2}\pi or -\frac{3}{2}\pi.

However, on combining (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) with the connection formula (LABEL:eq:IG.EID.13), with m=1 , we derive E_{p}\left(z\right)\sim\frac{2\pi ie^{-p\pi i}}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}z^{p-1}+ \frac{e^{-z}}{z}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{{\left(p\right)_{s}}}{z^{s}}, valid as z\to\infty in any closed sector within \frac{1}{2}\pi<\operatorname{ph}z<\frac{7}{2}\pi ; compare (LABEL:eq:IG.AEE.4).

Since the ray \operatorname{ph}z=\frac{3}{2}\pi is well away from the new boundaries, the compound expansion (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.G) yields much more accurate results when \operatorname{ph}z\to\frac{3}{2}\pi.

In effect, (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.G) “corrects” (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) by introducing a term that is relatively exponentially small in the neighborhood of \operatorname{ph}z=\pi , is increasingly significant as \operatorname{ph}z passes from \pi to \frac{3}{2}\pi , and becomes the dominant contribution after \operatorname{ph}z passes \frac{3}{2}\pi.
See also §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.SP.

The procedure followed in §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.CF enabled E_{p}\left(z\right) to be computed with as much accuracy in the sector \pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq 3\pi as the original expansion (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi.
We now increase substantially the accuracy of (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi by re-expanding the remainder term.
Optimum truncation in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) takes place at s=n-1 , with |p+n-1|=|z| , approximately.
Thus n=\rho-p+\alpha, where z=\rho e^{i\theta} , and |\alpha| is bounded as n\to\infty.

From (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.E) and the identity \frac{1}{1+t}=\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{s}t^{s}+(-1)^{n}\frac{t^{n}}{1+t}, subject to t\neq-1, we have E_{p}\left(z\right)=\frac{e^{-z}}{z}\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}(-1)^{s}\frac{{\left(p \right)_{s}}}{z^{s}}+(-1)^{n}\frac{2\pi}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}z^{p-1}F_{n+p} \left(z\right), where F_{n+p}\left(z\right)=\frac{e^{-z}}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{e^{-zt}t^{n+p- 1}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t=\frac{\Gamma\left(n+p\right)}{2\pi}\frac{E_{n+p}\left(z \right)}{z^{n+p-1}}.
With n given by (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.H), we have F_{n+p}\left(z\right)=\frac{e^{-z}}{2\pi}\int_{0}^{\infty}\exp\left(-\rho\left (te^{i\theta}-\ln t\right)\right)\frac{t^{\alpha-1}}{1+t}\mathrm{d}t.
For large \rho the integrand has a saddle point at t=e^{-i\theta}.
Following §LABEL:sec:AS.CI.SP, we rotate the integration path through an angle -\theta , which is valid by analytic continuation when -\pi<\theta<\pi.

Then by application of Laplace’s method (§§LABEL:sec:AS.CI.LM and LABEL:sec:AS.CI.SP), we have F_{n+p}\left(z\right)\sim\frac{e^{-i(\rho+\alpha)\theta}}{1+e^{-i\theta}}\frac {e^{-\rho-z}}{(2\pi\rho)^{1/2}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{a_{2s}(\theta,\alpha)} {\rho^{s}}, subject to \rho\to\infty, uniformly when \theta\in[-\pi+\delta,\pi-\delta] ( \delta>0 ) and |\alpha| is bounded. The coefficients are rational functions of \alpha and 1+e^{i\theta} , for example, a_{0}(\theta,\alpha)=1 , and a_{2}(\theta,\alpha)=\frac{1}{12}(6\alpha^{2}-6\alpha+1)-\frac{\alpha}{1+e^{i \theta}}+\frac{1}{(1+e^{i\theta})^{2}}.
Owing to the factor e^{-\rho} , that is, e^{-|z|} in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.M), F_{n+p}\left(z\right) is uniformly exponentially small compared with E_{p}\left(z\right).

For this reason the expansion of E_{p}\left(z\right) in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi-\delta supplied by (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.H), (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.J), and (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.M) is said to be exponentially improved.
If we permit the use of nonelementary functions as approximants, then even more powerful re-expansions become available.

One is uniformly valid for -\pi+\delta\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq 3\pi-\delta with bounded |\alpha| , and achieves uniform exponential improvement throughout 0\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\pi : F_{n+p}\left(z\right)\sim(-1)^{n}ie^{-p\pi i}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}\operatorname{ erfc}\left(\sqrt{\tfrac{1}{2}\rho}\,c(\theta)\right)-i\frac{e^{i\rho(\pi- \theta)}e^{-\rho-z}}{(2\pi\rho)^{1/2}}\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}\frac{h_{2s}(\theta, \alpha)}{\rho^{s}}\right).

Here \operatorname{erfc} is the complementary error function (§LABEL:sec:ER.DF.ER), and c(\theta)=\sqrt{2(1+e^{i\theta}+i(\theta-\pi))}, the branch being continuous with c(\theta)\sim\pi-\theta as \theta\to\pi.

Also, h_{2s}(\theta,\alpha)=\frac{e^{i\alpha(\pi-\theta)}}{1+e^{-i\theta}}a_{2s}( \theta,\alpha)+(-1)^{s-1}i\frac{1\cdot 3\cdot 5\cdot\cdot\cdot(2s-1)}{(c( \theta))^{2s+1}}, with a_{2s}(\theta,\alpha) as in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.M), (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.N).
In particular, h_{0}(\theta,\alpha)=\frac{e^{i\alpha(\pi-\theta)}}{1+e^{-i\theta}}-\frac{i}{c (\theta)}.
For the sector -3\pi+\delta\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\pi-\delta the conjugate result applies.
Further details for this example are supplied in ( ) .
See also ( , Chapter 6) , and ( ) .

Two different asymptotic expansions in terms of elementary functions, (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) and (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.G), are available for thegeneralized exponential integral in the sector \frac{1}{2}\pi<\operatorname{ph}z<\frac{3}{2}\pi.
That the change in their forms is discontinuous, even though the function being approximated is analytic, is an example of the Stokes phenomenon.
Where should the change-over take place?
Can it be accomplished smoothly?
Satisfactory answers to these questions were found by ( ) ; see also the survey by ( ) .
These answers are linked to the terms involving the complementary error function in the more powerful expansions typified by the combination of (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.J) and (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.O).
Thus if 0\leq\theta\leq\pi-\delta ( <\pi ), then c(\theta) lies in the right half-plane.

Hence from §LABEL:sec:ER.AE.CE \operatorname{erfc}\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}\rho}\;c(\theta)\right) is of the same exponentially-small order of magnitude as the contribution from the other terms in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.O) when \rho is large.

On the other hand, when \pi+\delta\leq\theta\leq 3\pi-\delta , c(\theta) is in the left half-plane and \operatorname{erfc}\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}\rho}\;c(\theta)\right) differs from 2 by an exponentially-small quantity.

In the transition through \theta=\pi , \operatorname{erfc}\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}\rho}\;c(\theta)\right) changes very rapidly, but smoothly, from one form to the other; compare the graph of its modulus in Figure LABEL:fig:AS.RTSP.A in the case \rho=100.

In particular, on the ray \theta=\pi greatest accuracy is achieved by (a) taking the average of the expansions (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.F) and (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.G), followed by (b) taking account of the exponentially-small contributions arising from the terms involving h_{2s}(\theta,\alpha) in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.O).
Rays (or curves) on which one contribution in a compound asymptotic expansion achieves maximum dominance over another are called Stokes lines ( \theta=\pi in the present example).
As these lines are crossed exponentially-small contributions, such as that in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.G), are “switched on” smoothly, in the manner of the graph in FigureLABEL:fig:AS.RTSP.A.
For higher-order Stokes phenomena see ( ) and ( ) .
Expansions similar to (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.O) can be constructed for many other special functions.

However, to enjoy the resurgence property (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.IS) we often seek instead expansions in terms of the F -functions introduced in §LABEL:sec:AS.RTSP.EIE, leaving the connection of the error-function type behavior as an implicit consequence of this property of the F -functions.
In this context the F -functions are calledterminants, a name introduced by ( ) .
For illustration, we give re-expansions of the remainder terms in the expansions (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.H) arising in differential-equation theory.
For notational convenience assume that the original differential equation (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.A) is normalized so that \lambda_{2}-\lambda_{1}=1.
(This means that, if necessary, z is replaced by z/(\lambda_{2}-\lambda_{1}).
) From (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.L), (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.M) it is then seen that the optimum number of terms, n , in (LABEL:eq:AS.DE.N) is approximately |z|.
We set w_{j}(z)=e^{\lambda_{j}z}z^{\mu_{j}}\sum_{s=0}^{n-1}\frac{a_{s,j}}{z^{s}}+R_{n }^{(j)}(z), subject to j=1,2, and expand

Then as z\to\infty , with |n-|z|| bounded and m fixed, R_{m,n}^{(1)}(z)=\begin{cases}O\left(e^{-|z|-z}z^{-m}\right),&|\operatorname{ ph}z|\leq\pi,\\ O\left(z^{-m}\right),&\pi\leq|\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{5}{2}\pi-\delta, \end{cases} , R_{m,n}^{(2)}(z)=\begin{cases}O\left(e^{-|z|+z}z^{-m}\right),&0\leq \operatorname{ph}z\leq 2\pi,\\ O\left(z^{-m}\right),&-\frac{3}{2}\pi+\delta\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq 0\text{ and }2\pi\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq\frac{7}{2}\pi-\delta,\end{cases}
uniformly with respect to \operatorname{ph}z in each case.
The relevant Stokes lines are \operatorname{ph}z=\pm\pi for w_{1}(z) , and \operatorname{ph}z=0,2\pi for w_{2}(z).

In addition to achieving uniform exponential improvement, particularly in |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\pi for w_{1}(z) , and 0\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq 2\pi for w_{2}(z) , the re-expansions (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.S), (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.T) are resurgent.

In this way we arrive at hyperasymptotic expansions.

subsection.title: Direct Numerical Transformations

para.sentence: The transformations in §LABEL:sec:NM.AOC for summing slowly convergent series can also be very effective when applied to divergent asymptotic series.

A simple example is provided by Euler’s transformation (§LABEL:sec:NM.AOC.EUL) applied to the asymptotic expansion for the exponential integral (§LABEL:sec:EX.AE.EI): e^{x}E_{1}\left(x\right)\sim\sum_{s=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{s}\frac{s!}{x^{s+1}}, subject to x\to+\infty.
The numerically smallest terms are the 5th and 6th.
Truncation after 5 terms yields 0.17408, compared with the correct value e^{5}E_{1}\left(5\right)=0.17042\dots.

We now compute the forward differences \Delta^{j} , j=0,1,2,\dots , of the moduli of the rounded values of the first 6 neglected terms: \Delta^{0}=0.00768, \Delta^{1}=0.00154, \Delta^{2}=0.00214, \Delta^{3}=0.00192, \Delta^{4}=0.00280, \Delta^{5}=0.0043 4 Multiplying these differences by (-1)^{j}2^{-j-1} and summing, we obtain 0.00384-0.00038+0.00027-0.00012+0.00009-0.00007=0.00363.
Subtraction of this result from the sum of the first 5 terms in (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.X) yields 0.17045, which is much closer to the true value.
The process just used is equivalent to re-expanding the remainder term of the original asymptotic series (LABEL:eq:AS.RTSP.W) in powers of 1/(x+5) and truncating the new series optimally.
Further improvements in accuracy can be realized by making a second application of the Euler transformation; see ( , pp. 540–543) .
Similar improvements are achievable by Aitken’s \Delta^{2} -process, Wynn’s \epsilon -algorithm, and other acceleration transformations.
For a comprehensive survey see ( ) .
The following example, based on ( ) , illustrates theirpower.

For large |z| , with |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq\frac{3}{2}\pi-\delta ( <\frac{3}{2}\pi ), the Whittaker function of the second kind has the asymptotic expansion (§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.ASZ) W_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right)\sim\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}a_{n}, in which a_{n}=\frac{e^{-z/2}}{z^{n-\kappa}n!}\left(\mu^{2}-(\kappa-\tfrac{1}{2})^{2} \right)\*\left(\mu^{2}-(\kappa-\tfrac{3}{2})^{2}\right)\*\cdot\cdot\cdot\left( \mu^{2}-(\kappa-n+\tfrac{1}{2})^{2}\right).

However, direct numerical transformations need to be used with care.
Their extrapolation is based on assumed forms of remainder terms that may not always be appropriate for asymptotic expansions.
